citations.title: Pharmacogenetics of anti-cancer drugs: State of the art and implementation - recommendations of the French National Network of Pharmacogenetics.
citations.summary: Individualized treatment is of special importance in oncology because the drugs used for chemotherapy have a very narrow therapeutic index. Pharmacogenetics may contribute substantially to clinical routine for optimizing cancer treatment to limit toxic effects while maintaining efficacy. This review presents the usefulness of pharmacogenetic tests for some key applications: dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase (DPYD) genotyping for fluoropyrimidine (5-fluorouracil, capecitabine), UDP glucuronosylstransferase (UGT1A1) for irinotecan and thiopurine S-methyltransferase (TPMT) for thiopurine drugs. Depending on the level of evidence, the French National Network of Pharmacogenetics (RNPGx) has issued three levels of recommendations for these pharmacogenetic tests: essential, advisable, and potentially useful. Other applications, for which the level of evidence is still discussed, will be evoked in the final section of this review.

textMarkdown.html:
The French National Network of Pharmacogenetics (RNPGx) publication about the state of the art and clinical implementation — recommendations from the French National Network of Pharmacogenetics for anti-cancer drugs states:

the polymorphism of the genes implicated in the pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of MTX can enable clinicians to optimize treatment while limiting the risk of toxicity. To date, several polymorphisms are associated with plasma levels of MTX, and drug efficacy and toxicity. Among these, two polymorphisms of the MTHFR gene that codes for methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase, c.677C>T (Ala222Val)rs1801133 and c.1298A>C (Glu429Ala)rs1801131 and reduces MTHFR enzymatic activity have been identified. The risk of developing MTX related toxicity, especially hepatic, gastrointestinal toxicity, leucopenia, neurotoxicity, have been significantly associated with c.677C>T in several studies and confirmed in a meta-analysis in 2012 [Article:22528943]. Nevertheless, a recent metaanalysis including 24 pediatric studies concluded that there is no association between the MTHFR variants and toxicity [Article:23089671]

Recently, several polymorphisms of the SLCO1B1 gene, notably rs4149081 and rs11045879 have been strongly associated for the first time with MTX clearance and gastrointestinal toxicity [Article:19901119]. These results were duplicated independently in the Genome Wide Association Study (GWAS) [Article:23233662]. In conclusion, despite the absence of a pharmacogenetic marker for the use of MTX in routine clinical practice, SLCO1B1 polymorphisms play an important role in the pharmacokinetics of MTX toxicity in oncology patients and have provided promising results. Other MTX transporters could be of interest but further study is needed.

Thus, according to the level of evidence classification of RNPGx recommendations for pharmacogenetic testing — essential, advisable, potentially useful — MTX pharmacogenetic tests are potentially useful in cancer patients.
